content: thirsty thursday y'all this week we're mixing up something perfect for this cooler rainy weather if you're like me just want to sell in the couch and cuddle may I can't help it and I need a drink to go without right so we're gonna mix up an Irish coffee featuring some whiskey so let's get started so this week's recipe for the Irish coffee is pretty simple you're going to need one glass of coffee this may or may not be instant I can't really handle anything else but anyways a cup of coffee and then you're gonna add in an ounce and a half of Irish whiskey Jameson whatever you like pour that in there and then we're going to add in 1 teaspoon of some brown sugar and mix up to once you have that all nice and mixed you can top with some heavy cream whipped cream whatever you're feeling I think whipped cream is a good idea this week so add in some whipped cream and you have a delicious irish coffee with some whiskey i'm sure for some of you this whiskey coffee cocktail looks like a heavenly combination and it is i mean look how good that looks with the whipped cream on top hmm all admit i'm not the biggest coffee fan but you got some whiskey and whipped cream and i am so there so go mix this up play starbucks barista and make you a little cocktail i hope you'll enjoy this week and i'll see you all again next week this is when Kathleen cook helping you get your drink on with another edition of thirsty thursday Cheers

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: when it comes to pairing great food with great coffee it's not just enough to think of the food you'll be serving but maybe what time of day it is or what the occasion might be so when it comes to something like brunch where we have sweet and savory it's morning it's lunch I like to do an Irish coffee it's a classic that really has no rules so I'm going to start by grinding my coffee fresh so we're gonna scoop our freshly ground coffee into our Florida filter now you see me settling the grounds because I want to make sure i get enough coffee in here and then I'm just gonna tamp it down you can see I can easily turn this upside down and the coffee stays in there that tells you you packed it well so put this in the espresso machine and I'm going to start my shots now if you noticed I had my shot glasses on top of the machine the machine is warm so that will begin to preheat those glasses so that when the freshest press of it it maintains all that heat and I get nice long lasting kruppa I like to have a little sweeter and I'm going to do to sugar cubes a sugar cube for each shot and you can see we have tons of crema they're just what we're looking for and I'm going to give it just a quick stir to kind of break up those cubes you could use Baker's sugar here so it's a little finer anything is perfectly fine because i'm using espresso i'm gonna add some hot water to dilute it you just dilute the espresso like this so i use Irish whiskey Irish whiskey for the Irish coffee and i like to use Bailey's in mind the nice creamy texture that the baby's dad I think it adds such a nice touch one final quick stir and again the classic recipe calls for some lightly whipped cream on top so I'm going to do two scoops really be indulgent there is nothing better with brunch than a fantastic Irish coffee and with these tips you're one step closer to being a Breville barista you

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: Hello, my name is Michalis Dimitrakopoulos and I am the world coffee in good spirits champion 2016 and the proud barista of the Underdog Today I made for you an Irish coffee so I am using 15 grams of an Ethiopian   Coffee called Tchembe from Ninety Plus and it´s located near Gedeo Yirgacheffe harvested by Ninety Plus It´s variety, it's a natural process and it's cultivated at almost 2000 meters above sea level We, at the Underdog roasted it just 8 days ago It´s a delightfull coffee sweet strawberry taste followed by jasmine and vanilla notes in the cup finishing on a delicate delight mouthfeel in my glass I will add 20 ml of Jameson Caskmates Irish Whiskey 20 ml of cane sugar syrup homemade cane sugar syrup and of course my freshly brewed Tchembe from my chemex now I gently stir in order to homogenize And I will put the cream over the top Please, enjoy my Irish Coffee

transcript.text: Hello, my name is Michalis Dimitrakopoulos
and I am the world coffee in good spirits champion 2016
and the proud barista of the Underdog
Today I made for you an Irish coffee
so I am using
15 grams of an Ethiopian   Coffee
called Tchembe
from Ninety Plus and it´s located near Gedeo Yirgacheffe
harvested by Ninety Plus
It´s variety, it's a natural process and it's cultivated at almost 2000 meters above sea level
We, at the Underdog roasted it just 8 days ago
It´s a delightfull coffee
sweet strawberry taste
followed by jasmine and vanilla notes in the cup
finishing on a delicate delight mouthfeel
in my glass I will add
20 ml of Jameson Caskmates Irish Whiskey
20 ml of cane sugar syrup
homemade cane sugar syrup
and of course my freshly brewed Tchembe from my chemex
now I gently stir in order to homogenize
And I will put the cream over the top
Please, enjoy my Irish Coffee

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: hello today we're going to make a traditional Irish coffee it's not only a fairly simple drink to make but it's also a nice treat to have after a meal especially when you have dinner guests so we'll get started by making sure that we have everything that we need you're going to need your coffeemaker Irish whiskey brown sugar and heavy cream you're going to need a hand mixer and Bowl coffee cup shot glass and a large and small spoon we'll start by brewing some regular ground coffee next you'll with the heavy cream until it thickens you want it to be similar to a batter or a heavy soup and have some body to it once you reach this stage just set it aside add one teaspoon of brown sugar and one shot of whiskey and then add your craft leaving enough room for the cream about an inch or so then give it a stir now you'll take the larger spoon and you'll turn it upside down and hold it over your glass above the coffee with your other hand you're going to pour the cream over the back of the spoon so it sits on top raising this phone if you need to you'll have about one into the cream so there you have it let's taste it um it's really delicious it tasted sweet and creamy with just a little bit of whiskey and I think you mean you guys to enjoy this taste of the Emerald Isle Cheers

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: hi everyone I'm Clara from the kitchen kitchen and today on 10 second living I'm going to show you how to make irish coffee irish coffee is one of my favorite cold weather cocktails it's hot it has whiskey it has whipped cream it is super delicious and it's very easy to put together so I have a French press of hot coffee ready to go I have vanilla infused Irish whiskey and it's kind of what it sounds like I took Irish whiskey put a vanilla bean in it and basically let it sit around for about a week and gets a lot of really great flavor and then i have my cinnamon whipped cream so it's whipped cream with a little bit of cinnamon mixed in really great flavor and i do a ratio of like three ounces coffee one ounce whiskey but do what you want if you really love whiskey you could make it happen half if you just want like a little nip nothing too big you can do just like a half ounce or something but this is it so let's get started poor together the coffee and the vanilla infused whiskey top with cinnamon whipped cream and stir to combine all right right Irish whiskey is done it's time to give it a try hmm is really good I love this because it's really balanced it's not too intense or too sweet it's not really a dessert and I like that I like tasting the whiskey however if you do want this to be a little more like a dessert a little richer little creamier you can definitely add more of the whipping cream or the whipped cream and you can sort of enjoy it more as a dessert that way but I like it like this with a whiskey really coming through for more recipes like this one check out my blog the kitschy kitchen calm

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: okay so coffee drinks there are a lot of them out there that most of them tend to be a little bit sweet more intended for after-dinner kind of GUI all kinds of sugary ingredients but the best one out there is more appropriate for breakfast that's Irish coffee real simple cocktail that originated at the Shannon Airport in Ireland which is simply Irish whiskey sugar coffee and then fresh whipped cream but the recipe that we're gonna make today and that's really become popularized around the world is from the Buena Vista Hotel in San Francisco and it really comes down to the technique in this drink real key here is to make sure you pre-heat the glass use some steaming hot water pre-heat your coffee coffee cocktail mug here and make sure you have a nice and hot because the key is if you once you put in the whiskey you add the coffee to it and it's gonna bring the temperature down so you want to get it as hot as possible once you've done that pour that out and we're just gonna add a single sugar cube in the bottom of the glass I'm gonna do about an ounce and a half of Jameson Irish whiskey you can also use Bushmills or something a little higher in like redbreast if you'd like and then we're gonna fill with coffee and then make sure you leave plenty of room at the top for some fresh whipped cream now you can make whipped cream really really easily at home with some heavy whipping cream a little bit of simple syrup and just shake it up in a cocktail shaker without ice really well and then just spoon it over the top or if you've got a handy ISI canister charge it and then just layer it right over the top of the drink I'm gonna add a straw and there you have it the point it is to Irish coffee

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: how to make an Irish coffee hello and welcome to videojug we've come to meet bar in London where head bartender Jerry Calabrese a is going to show us how to make an Irish coffee this drink was invented to warm you up on a cold winter evening but they taste just as good any time with the year step one you will need two cups of hot coffee 25 milliliters of Irish whiskey brown sugar a little double cream for whipping and one jug of hot water here's that list again you will also need the following utensils a stemmed glass a five milliliter bar spoon or normal teaspoon and a whisk step 2 whip the cream put the cream in a jug or bowl and whip lightly step 3 heat the glass hold the glass over some steaming water for a few seconds to heat it this prevents it from cracking step 4 sweeten it up put one teaspoon of sugar in the glass use brown sugar if you can step 5 pour in the whiskey now we're 25 milliliters of whiskey step 6 add coffee pour in the coffee living room at the top for the cream step 7 top with cream spoon some of the whipped cream over the hot coffee don't mix it in it should float on top done you

grandmas getting a little grouchy slipping one of these she'll calm down quickly so the first step is to get a fair amount of piping hot coffee gonna find your prettiest little mug add a good teaspoon of sugar and just stir that to dissolve if you don't normally have sugar in your coffee I recommend it in this cocktail it needs a little sweetness after that we're going to add the Irish part a good dose of Irish whiskey about an ounce and a half right on top and we're going to leave just a little bit of room on top and then in a little mason jar we've got some heavy whipping cream in here and I've been shaking this four minutes and I need another minute to do it you really got to shake the heck out of this thing to get it fully froth so let's get to work now that we have it about this title: Make Irish Coffee
content: one of the classic and most popular digestive drinks are after-dinner drinks in the world as an Irish coffee you may only call this drink an Irish coffee if it is made with Irish whiskey whiskey from Ireland this is the instant way where we use a Irish Coffee glass a teaspoon of coffee two teaspoons of sugar and a 30ml shot of Irish whiskey stir all ingredients together until they are well mixed the coffee the sugar and the whiskey and then add some boiling water making sure that you have a spoon in the glass to conduct at the heat so the glass doesn't crack and gently mix all of the ingredients with the boiling water ensure that you stop an eddy or Whirlpool effect which would drag it the fresh cream down into the drink and then gently poured a fresh cream onto the bowl of the spoon letting the cream flow gently off the spoon at its own pace this way it ensures that the cream floats on top of the coffee sometimes served with a sprinkle of chocolate sometimes served on a doily plate never served with a stirring spoon an Irish coffee

content: hey guys thanks for checking out another an idiot slicker today I am making a drink called the Irish winter now this filming I just got finished up with the Irish coffee I'm going to link to that down below because that is a classic and you should try that one out but this is a slight variation on the Irish coffee and since I have some coffee left over some whipping cream left over and of course i still have my whiskey I mean it will make this cool variation as well it's a little bit sweeter a little less strong because it don't use as much Jamison as the Irish coffee actually we're going to use some kahlua as well or tia maria any coffee liqueur and we're going to make something very similar yet different enough to make a difference so we're going to get started and I'm going to use my same glass that I use for the Irish coffee because yeah I paid for them and I mazal get my use out of them but you can use just a stem to wine glass or something similar to that or even a coffee mug as well to make this drink but we're going to start off by putting some hot water in it and now my glass is nice and warm I'm just going to dump that out because we don't want to serve it in a cold glass that would just be stupid you don't serve hot soup in a cold Bowl you don't serve hot coffee drink in a cold glass so once we do that we're just going to take one or I'm sorry three-quarters ounces three quarter ounces of Irish whiskey pour that into our glass I'm going to take three quarters ounces of coffee liqueur and if you didn't guess we're going to pour that into our glass as well so once we do that we're going to fill it up with coffee leaving some space at the top for our whipping cream so now that I have that little gap at the top I've seen people use the canned whipped cream now what I did was I took whipping cream and whisked it you can also use a electric mixer if you want to do that to make it thick so it'll still poor but as you'll be able to see it's thick enough that when we pour it down the back of a bar spoon it floats on the top of the surface so it is thick and it's really frothy creamy I love it actually I kind of got a little bit thicker than maybe I should have but you know it's still pretty good and the reason we do that is you want to have that hot coffee and be able to drink it through that cold layer of cream so you hit with that cold layer of cream first before the hot coffee hits your mouth and it really results in a delicious drink huh it's not that much different than our traditional irish coffee it does have a distinctly more tameness to it because you know we're not using this drink uses about half as much Irish whiskey and it replaces it with the coffee liqueur so you do definitely feel less burn from it you get the flavor from the Irish whiskey without as much burn so if you don't if you personally think in Irish coffees a little bit too strong you might want to try this you might actually really enjoy this one well guys that's it for today this was the Irish winter coffee drink and now that I've just downed two drinks with coffee I've down to drinks with coffee uh probably about three and a half ounces of Irish whiskey and some coffee liqueur and it's about time for bed so that's going to be really easy for me to go to sleep I think so if you're as energized as I am at this point maybe you should subscribe to my channel and check out some other drinks that I've made in the past that way you'll also get updates for any future drinks that I make I post weekly ones so you can get all of the latest info on an idiot slicker until next time though as I always say remember it's okay to drink like an idiot thanks for watching

kettle and preheating our mug the other secret ingredient to making a good Irish coffee is whipped cream now let's call it to plate that in order to make a good whipped cream you need a heavy mixing title: Make Irish Coffee
content:
How to Make an Irish Coffee. After dinner, after hours, or even after a
long St. Patrick's Day, Irish coffee is the one delicious pick-me-up you won't find at
your local coffeehouse. You will need 1 1/2 oz. Irish whiskey 6 oz. hot coffee 2 tsp. brown
sugar Whipped cream A stemmed glass coffee mug or a regular coffee mug A spoon and a
measuring jigger. Step 1. Run hot water slowly over the glass or mug
until it’s at room temperature, or warmer, and dry it. Pouring hot coffee into a cold glass could
cause the glass to crack. Step 2. Add brown sugar. Step 3. Pour in the whiskey and hot coffee, leaving
a bit of room at the top for whipped cream. For a cold version of this, chill sweetened
coffee before adding the whiskey, or freeze some in an ice cube tray. Step 4. Stir well, until the sugar to dissolves completely. Step 5. Squirt or spoon a dollop of whipped cream
so it simply sets on top of the drink. Step 6. Do not stir—not only does the hot drink
taste better sipped through the cream, it stays warmer longer with the cream on top. Did you know The drink Irish Coffee was devised
in 1942 at an exclusive Irish airport to welcome American VIPs like Humphrey Bogart and Eleanor
Roosevelt.

transcript.text: How to Make an Irish Coffee.

After dinner, after hours, or even after a
long St. Patrick's Day, Irish coffee is the

one delicious pick-me-up you won't find at
your local coffeehouse.
You will need 1 1/2 oz.

Irish whiskey 6 oz. hot coffee 2 tsp. brown
sugar Whipped cream A stemmed glass coffee

mug or a regular coffee mug A spoon and a
measuring jigger.
Step 1.

Run hot water slowly over the glass or mug
until it’s at room temperature, or warmer,
and dry it.

Pouring hot coffee into a cold glass could
cause the glass to crack.
Step 2.
Add brown sugar.
Step 3.

Pour in the whiskey and hot coffee, leaving
a bit of room at the top for whipped cream.

For a cold version of this, chill sweetened
coffee before adding the whiskey, or freeze
some in an ice cube tray.
Step 4.
Stir well, until the sugar to dissolves completely.
Step 5.

Squirt or spoon a dollop of whipped cream
so it simply sets on top of the drink.
Step 6.

Do not stir—not only does the hot drink
taste better sipped through the cream, it
stays warmer longer with the cream on top.

Did you know The drink Irish Coffee was devised
in 1942 at an exclusive Irish airport to welcome

American VIPs like Humphrey Bogart and Eleanor
Roosevelt.

title: Make Irish Coffee
content:
Warm up this holiday season with a traditional Irish coffee, make from coffee or espresso, Irish whiskey, sugar and cream. Today, we're going to be using premium Nespresso compatible capsules from HiLine Coffee to
make a simple Irish coffee. To make this recipe, you'll also need 1 teaspoon sugar, 1 shot of Irish whiskey, 1 shot of Kahlua, whipped cream and a dash of nutmeg. First, insert a HiLine capsule into your Nespresso machine. Now press the lungo button to pull your espresso shot into a mug. Repeat these step to brew an additional shot of espresso into the mug using a new HiLine capsule. Next, add the sugar, Irish Whiskey and Kahlua to the espresso and stir. Top with whipped cream and a dash of nutmeg. This hearty, traditional Irish coffee beverage has been enjoyed for centuries and is now
a part of many holiday celebrations as well.

content: this drink is called an Irish coffee which is a favorite drink from that great city of San Francisco legend has it that it was first served at a bar called the Buena Vista cafe which is right on the San Francisco Bay and it's at the end of the cable car and if you ever get to San Francisco and it's cold and foggy you go into this bar it's full of people and everybody well almost everybody is drinking irish coffees so the first thing that we need is a cup or a special glass is a special tempered glass so if we put hot things in and it's not going to crack and we're going to use Irish whiskey now Irish whiskey has a distinct flavor whiskey flavor and it can only come from Ireland and there's lots of different brands of Irish whiskey so we're going to use one ounce so come on out there of our Irish whiskey then we're going to take fresh coffee fill it up now sometimes people like a sweet and coffee so if they like this the sweeter we would put a little bit of sugar in there to sweeten it up then what we're going to do is we're going to take whipped cream shake this up top it off with whipped cream like so and then we would serve it so it's really Irish whiskey coffee and whipped cream now they have many variations of these coffee drinks that oftentimes our popular after-dinner drinks especially in cold weather climates you could have Mexican coffee made with kahlua Jamaican coffee made with Tia Maria so it the variety goes on endless so but this is the most popular Irish coffee right there

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: it's really important when you're making an Irish coffee at home to do what I call flashing the glass we put we put our hot water and the vessel that the drink is going to be served in to take away any chill from it well so what I have here is a brown sugar simple syrup it's two parts brown sugar one part water and then a heavy whipping cream that I hand whipped for the guests to these are nice and hot to the touch the thing about this is you never want to put a hot drink it to a cold glass an Irish coffee it's a very simple drink two ounces of Irish whiskey right in that hot glass then we'll take and measure one part of the brown sugar syrup one-ounce this adds a nice richness to the drink and then we'll just top it leaving plenty of room for the whipped cream now the thing about Irish coffees you want to drink it through the whipped cream just going to float right on top then we just garnish it with three coffee beans there you have an Irish coffee that's just a great winter warmer and Cheers

Patrick's Day but also anytime it's cold outside this drink is sure to warm you up here's what you'll need 2 ounces of Irish whiskey we like the good stuff so we're going to be using Jameson 2 tablespoons of brown sugar a double shot of espresso and some fresh-made whipped cream and for that you're going to need 1/2 cup of heavy cream 1/2 teaspoon of pure vanilla extract and 2 teaspoons of confectionery sugar when you make whipped cream it helps to have everything cold so I've had my bowl and freezer for a little while and I just took my heavy cream out of the fridge so I'm going to add get to that point oK we've sped things up a bit but I'm starting to get those soft peaks so now is the time to add the vanilla and sugar now I'm going to continue whipping until I get some stiff peaks you just want to be careful not to go too far around so it's going to get clumpy all right that looks good now I'm going to put this back in the fridge to keep it cold while we make the rest of our drink all right so I'm going to be using an Irish coffee mug to put my drink together and I'll first add the two tablespoons of brown sugar and the two ounces of Irish whiskey all right now what I'm content: hey y'all I'm Andrea from andrea's cocktails whether it's sitting in the morning with my cappuccino catching up on social media talking for hours with my parents over a cup or unwinding with friends over drinks coffee seems to be a huge part of my life around the holidays I love to add a sweet twist to an after-dinner coffee with my chocolate cherry Irish coffee start by stirring cherry juice into whipped cream then mix hot coffee either espresso or regular coffee with chocolate cherry Bailey dollop with whipped cream then garnish with chocolate shavings and add a chocolate-covered cherry this drink is sure to put the cherry on top of your next holiday party for more cocktail ideas and holiday favorites stop by the blog at Andrea's cook tales calm

in the coffee maker. So, without further adieu let's go do heavy
cream first, we'll refrigerate it, while that’s being refrigerated we'll prep the cup with
hot water, after adding hot water to the cup we'll put the sugar in whiskey in, stir it
and dissolve the sugar. Brew the coffee. Bring the cream back out of the refrigerator
and pour it on top and we'll have an Irish coffee. So let’s begin. First step: Puts some cream in the cup. We
are going to whisk this. To have it nice and thick to go over the hot coffee. Ah, kay, so. [whisking] Sometimes you just gotta do what you gotta
do. [whisking] As you can see its getting thicker. [whisking] That should do it. We'll whip it up again a little later, now
we'll put this in the fridge. So it keeps it nice and cold while we're doing
the rest of the preparations. Alright, so, ah, we want to put some hot water
in the cup first. [water pouring] Prime the cup! So that way your, we're going to pour
cold cream in here we're going to put room temperature whiskey in here. So, by doing
that we're going to be cooling down the cup. So we want to have a cup that is already hot.

and… Alright, hopefully this isn't going to make

Well, just in case I have to swap out cups. [coffee pouring] Add some coffee to the Irish. [spoon stirring] Looks like it might be okay. Still plenty

show you if I can here. Here's how it looks coming out of the frigerator.
I'm going to go ahead and whip it one more time so its pretty thick. Aw, heck with it, yeah I'm gonna whip it one
more time. Nope, yep, nope, yep, indecisiveness So, keep it cool on top, put the cream on
top, pour it over the spoon, in theory. Oh my! It poured over a little bit. Hehehe, alrighty. Alight, so, we've made our Irish coffee. You can see here, looks like did a little
bit of a mixup, maybe too much cream. Should be all coffee here and shouldn’t
be this much cream. So, maybe what I need to do is whip it more
or maybe not as much cream next time. Ahhh! Outstanding! The cream is cold on top, the coffee is nice
and hot and its just got that warmth from good old Irish coffee-whiskey. Cheers! Have a nice day!

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: good afternoon welcome back to the library lounge this is Chris McMillan in association with nola.com bringing you your cocktail weekly cocktail feature best cocktails new audience today for your drinking pleasure we're going to present the after-dinner classic the Irish coffee the Irish coffee was reputed to have been admitted at coins flying boat station in Ireland in the early 1940s coins was a airport where pontoon airplanes landed and was the site of the first transatlantic flights from America's Europe it was reputed to have benefited for Americans who came in in a cold and damp evening and they wanted something to warm them up and drive them off it was introduced in the United States at the widow Bista cafe in San Francisco where they're reputed to have served over 2,000 a day we're going to begin with our cup of our Irish coffee cup I'm going to go ahead and put some hot water in the cup so because you never want to put hot coffee into a cold cup I'm sorry and worn the cup up but we're going to begin by adding a small amount one shot Irish whiskey [Music] for our sweetener today we're going to use Demerara sugar which is a natural unrefined sugar that is a very rich in flavor and is the perfect complement to a cup of a good cup of coffee it's available at gourmet food stores specialty food markets even Walmart soaked in log give Aurora sugar we're going to add a small amount of coffee to this to warm it up to put our sugar into solution we just want to stir that up till we see that all the sugar has all the sugars dissolved good and climbing huh and then we're going to top this off with fresh hot coffee we don't want to a drowned the whiskey or the sugar and coffee so we're not going to fill it all the way at the top and then we're going to top it off with some fresh whipped cream when you whip the cream you don't have to whip the cream to where it's all the way and stuff you just want to get it good and aerated so that it floats on the top of one of the great pleasures of this coffee is the dual sensation of drinking the hot coffee through the cold cream when it's made properly you'll see that it has that beautiful definition between the coffee and the cream itself there you have it the classic after-dinner drink the Irish coffee delicious look forward to seeing you again next week where we're going to present the Brandy Alexander cheers to you

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: TheFNDC.com presents Drinks with Diablo Morning with Leprechauns Welcome back to Drinks with Diablo with your host, Jöhnny Dîablø And today we're making an Irish drink, it's called Morning with Leprechauns. What you're going to need is some Baileys Irish cream, Jameson Irish whiskey, some cold coffee, and a little bit of cherry brandy. So let's get started. It is an ounce and a half of your Irish cream. All this goes into a tall glass with ice. OK, an ounce of your Jameson or other Irish whiskey. I know it's not the only one, but it's just the best one. Okay, just a quarter of an ounce of your cherry brandy And then, top it off with about 3 ounces of cold coffee. [ pours black coffee into Mornings with Leprechauns ] Alright. Stir it up. And let's see how it tastes. [ drinks Morning With Leprechauns coffee ] Mmm. That tastes like Irish whiskey, but different. It's got a little kick, maybe the brandy adds a little bit. It's a lot like Irish coffee, but a little bit different. I kind of like that. It's pretty good. Anyway, if you want to find more drink recipes like this, Subscribe to our YouTube channel. We've got a RSS feed. You can also stop on by our website, TheFNDC.com Be sure to celebrate St. Patrick's Day, and give us a comment or two. And as always, thank you for being here - Happy Drinking. Morning with Leprechauns ~ 1 ½ oz Baileys Irish cream, 1 oz Jameson Irish whiskey, ¼ oz cherry brandy, 3 oz cold black coffee. Drinks with Diablo ~ A presentation of TheFNDC.com

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: Irish coffee it's the only drink in the world that provides in a single glass all four essential food groups alcohol caffeine sugar and fat Irish coffee was invented here in fines in 1943 in the month of October a fly's left fines on one of these flying boats and the Yankee Clipper and was heading for New York which its passengers when they hit very bad weather on the North Atlantic so after several hours of flying the pilots had to make a decision was going to continue to the broad ear or would he come back to fines so he decided he'd better turning back in the meantime the staff here had to be brought in to get everything ready for a food and drink to warm the passengers from they'd arrived so my grandfather would have gone out in horseback and called in the crew from the surrounding countryside the chef was Joe Sheridan a very innovative chef and he decided to add some good Irish whiskey into their coffees which would really warm them up and one of the passengers came up and said hey chef you said that was brilliant coffee you know he said was a Brazilian you used and Sheridan said no not at all that was Irish so does began the whole history of the wonderful drink we know today Irish coffee the key to a perfect Irish coffee is in temperature so first of all we have to heat the glass and so the glass doesn't break we'll put the tea spoon into the glass then empty out the boiling water and we're left with a really warm gas one teaspoon of brown sugar and then the next ingredient is our part I Rizzoli okay so you can use any whiskey really but the first Irish country was made with powers whiskey so we usually sit here in the museum and we do one full measure it's 35 millimeters and because we never know when to stop Roger Moore and then the next ingredient is our coffee we use beauties coffee here in anything and we just push in almost to the stuff and then we give it a really good stir and this is where it's just smell lovely and the last wish is the cream so we hold the TSP we hold one edge on top of the glass and the other on top of the coffee and we slightly cheat because we hook the computer screen okay so it helps us a little bit and then you just pour the cream slowly off the back of the spoon so that's this and how we have two left to say is Slainte sergeant that's it hmm

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: bringing the people behind our food to life whenever I entertain at home in the wintertime here in Portland I like to make Irish coffees for my friends I'm just going to show you a few easy steps so you can make these at home the first thing you want to do is use a nice coffee and Portland we're lucky to have local Roasters I'm using water Avenue for this and I also prefer French press and then grinding it fresh before you make the drinks while the grinder is working I'm going to start whipping my lips so the important thing with the whipped cream is that you're going to be pouring it on top of the drink so you don't want to stand up stiff like you would for pastries I just call this bar whipped cream so which is slightly different than that so I have the fresh ground coffee I'm going to use a nice French press and then we're going to reach to our hot coffee it's really important when you're making an Irish coffee at home to do what I call flashing the glass we put our hot water and the vessel that the drink is going to be served in to take away any chill from it so this takes about three minutes and while that's going I'm going to continue to start whipping my my whipped cream this is just a heavy whipping cream I'll just try to get it to thicken there's no sugar added and it's a little bit different than what you'd use in a kitchen when you would whip cream I want it to pour and you'll see how that is when I when I pour it onto the drink another main ingredient to an Irish Coffee is a simple syrup I'm using a brown sugar simple syrup and it's two parts of brown sugar and then one part of water then I'll just stir that together now the water is not hot on this we're just going to integrate the sugar and the water together you don't want to cook the sugar so we'll just let that dissolve together that's a two to one kind of rich brown sugar syrup just want to stir it to let everything dissolve together and then to serve I'll put it in a nice little vessel makes it easy to pour and easy to measure on the whipped cream you can see it's starting to thicken to the touch once it looks like it's thickening and it's going to pour nicely I'll also put that in a nice vessel for serving okay well so what I have here is a brown sugar simple syrup it's two parts brown sugar one part water and then a heavy whipping cream that I hand whipped for the guests I flash the glass I'll just go ahead and and dump the hot water so these are nice and hot to the touch the thing about this is you never want to put a hot drink into a cold glass an Irish coffee it's a very simple drink to parts of Irish whiskey in this case we're going to just measure two ounces so two ounces of Irish whiskey right in that hot glass then we'll take and measure one part of the brown sugar it's a rich brown sugar syrup so in this case one ounce this adds a nice richness to the drink big bold depth and flavor French press should be just about ready now about about three minutes in just want to plunge it down in there nice and then we'll just top it leaving plenty of room for the whipped cream now the thing about Irish coffees you want to drink it through the whipped cream really make it delicious whipped cream just going to float right on top the Irish copy was made in Dublin Ireland and about the 1950s it was brought to the boy of these two cafe in San Francisco then we just garnished it with three coffee beans there you have an Irish coffee it's just a great winter warmer enjoy your holidays Cheers you

title: Make Irish Coffee
content:
Irish Coffee was developed by an Irishman,
but its original taste-testers were Americans. A group of travelers arrived in Ireland on
a winter evening in the 1940s and were served coffee with whiskey to warm them up. When
the Americans asked what they were drinking, the Irishman told them it was "Irish Coffee."
Using a Keurig brewer, we're going to make Original Irish Coffee today with 100% Organic OneCup Breakfast Blend Coffee from Organic Coffee Company. For this recipe, you'll also need 1 tablespoon Brown Sugar, 3 tablespoons Irish Whiskey and some heavy cream to taste. First, insert a 100% Organic OneCup Breakfast Blend Coffee into your Keurig machine. Brew the coffee into a mug. Transfer the coffee to an Irish Coffee Mug until about ¾ full. Add the brown sugar and stir until dissolved. Then, add the Irish Whiskey and stir.
Top with heavy cream to taste, forming a collar by pouring the cream over the back of a spoon into the glass. While variations of Irish Coffee exist, this
method of preparation comes straight from Dublin. Enjoy on cold days, as originally
intended, or whenever you crave a special, savory cup of coffee. And the best part of the OneCup Single Serve Coffee from Organic Coffee Company is that it's 97% biodegradable, toss it in the trash with a clear conscience. If you Like this Coffee Recipe feel free to share, give us thumb up or comment. To see more Keurig Recipes subscribe to our channel.

Irish Coffee was developed by an Irishman,

coffee with whiskey to warm them up. When
the Americans asked what they were drinking,

the Irishman told them it was "Irish Coffee."
Using a Keurig brewer, we're going to make
Original Irish Coffee today with 100% Organic OneCup Breakfast Blend Coffee from Organic
Coffee Company. For this recipe, you'll also need 1 tablespoon
Brown Sugar, 3 tablespoons Irish Whiskey and some heavy cream to taste.
First, insert a 100% Organic OneCup Breakfast Blend Coffee into your Keurig machine.
Brew the coffee into a mug. Transfer the coffee to an Irish Coffee Mug
until about ¾ full. Add the brown sugar and stir until dissolved.

Then, add the Irish Whiskey and stir.
Top with heavy cream to taste, forming a collar
by pouring the cream over the back of a spoon into the glass.

While variations of Irish Coffee exist, this
method of preparation comes straight from

Dublin. Enjoy on cold days, as originally
intended, or whenever you crave a special,
savory cup of coffee. And the best part of the OneCup Single Serve
Coffee from Organic Coffee Company is that it's 97% biodegradable, toss it in the trash
with a clear conscience. If you Like this Coffee Recipe feel free to
share, give us thumb up or comment. To see more Keurig Recipes subscribe to our channel.

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: hey thirsty girls Hannah here this week we're going to be making the Irish coffee now the Irish coffee was actually invented at the Shannon Airport in Ireland a man named Jack Kepler and his friends Stanton delaplane in 1952 headed to Ireland to try this drink thought it was amazing and brought it back to the Buena Vista cafe in San Francisco where they still serve two thousand a day so if you were in the Bay Area i highly recommend you stop by and check it out let's make one of our own today alright you were going to start by preheating your glass so add some hot water your glass and dump it out I've already done that then you're going to add about 2 teaspoons of brown sugar to the bottom of your glass go then you're going to add about 2 ounces of jameson you don't have to use Jameson you can use your favorite Irish whiskey then you're going to muddle the two together until the brown sugar is nice and broken up in there so it shouldn't take too long I just want to make sure that you won't get any globs of brown sugar how about I do it alright then you're going to add about 4 ounces of coffee use your favorite coffee that will make the drink more delicious for you right and then you were going to top with homemade whipped cream now I highly suggest you make your own whipped cream you can just buy heavy whipping cream add it to a blender or you could also just put it in a bowl use a hand mixer or even put it in a shaker now even if you are lactose intolerant like me you can enjoy this drink with some whipped cream by using rice whipped cream that I purchased at whole foods so it's pretty exciting for me to get to have some whip cream on my drink all right now we'd love to hear your comments and thoughts and opinions on this recipe don't forget every person that comments on this recipe is automatically entered to win a fun thirsty go prize so until next time there's two girls Cheers

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: Take an Irish Coffee Cup or any other heat resistant glass. Fill it with boiling water and swing the glass carefully to heat it up. We need the high glass temperature to flambe the Whiskey later on. Empty the tempered glass and fill it with 3 teaspoons of brown cane sugar. As Irish Whiskey we use Roe & Co. An overproof Irish Whiskey which is ideal for flambe. Swing the glass till the sugar dissolves more and more... ...and flambe. You hear some noise that comes from the caramelizing process of the sugar. Now add a cup of fresh espresso.. ...and some whipped cream. Now our Irish Coffee is finished.

transcript.text: Take an Irish Coffee Cup or any other heat resistant glass.
Fill it with boiling water and swing the glass carefully to heat it up.
We need the high glass temperature to flambe the Whiskey later on.
Empty the tempered glass and fill it with 3 teaspoons of brown cane sugar.
As Irish Whiskey we use Roe & Co. An overproof Irish Whiskey which is ideal for flambe.
Swing the glass till the sugar dissolves more and more...
...and flambe.
You hear some noise that comes from the caramelizing process of the sugar.
Now add a cup of fresh espresso..
...and some whipped cream.
Now our Irish Coffee is finished.

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: hi since its st. Patrick's Day I thought I'd show you how to make a true Irish coffee if you go to a bar or a restaurant in the United States and order Irish coffee what he usually get is a cup of coffee with a shot of Irish whiskey and whipped cream on top it's not very good and it's not traditional so what you will need to make a real Irish coffee is hot strong coffee Irish whiskey of course you'll need sugar which I prefer the natural sugar and you'll need heavy whipping cream so start with a hot coffee don't fill the cup too tall because you're gonna have to add the whiskey and the whipping cream then put in your sugar give it a good stir while I'm talking socket and dissolve that for you then add your Irish whiskey and for the whipping cream we're not going to whip it we're just going to shake it till it's thickened the beautiful thing about this is if you do too much you could just put it in the fridge as a shaker and use it on your coffee another day so we'll shake that up until it's good in the sick and then what you want to do is take your spoon and lay it right on top of the coffee this will allow you to pour the cream onto the spoon and get that nice layer on top do not stir the coffee this is exactly how you drink it so that as you drink you get a little of the hot coffee with the cold cream and it's absolutely delicious

title: Make Irish Coffee
content: today we're going to make a classic Irish cocktail Irish coffee this trick you're gonna need an Irish coffee mug a measuring cup a bar spoon the coffeemaker a whisk and a bowl or in this case a large measuring cup this drinkies is whiskey coffee heavy cream and optionally a sugar cube in the books James Bond was a big whiskey drinker he drank whiskey almost as much as he drank coffee bourbon and Scotch were by far his favorite whiskies but when the mood seized him he also drank Canadian rye whiskey Tennessee whiskey and Irish whiskey the most common Irish whiskeys the blended Irish whiskeys are pot still whiskeys that are cut with me for grain alcohol essentially vodka so for Irish whiskey I was like using a single pot still whiskey or were used to be called a pure pottsville whiskey they're much more flavorful and robust green spot and redress to two great examples of single pot still whiskeys for this drink I'll use in green spot but feel free to use your favorite Irish whiskey I tend to not like a lot of sweeteners of my drinks this one's often made with sugar although bond never mentioned sugar in his drink however it works well on this one sugar will dissolve quickly in hot water or in this case coffee when it comes to cold drinks like the old-fashioned I tend to steer toward using simple syrup over sugar cubes that's because sugar has a hard time dissolving an alcohol particularly when it's cold but for hot drinks the sugar dissolves almost instantly as for the cream you want to float it on top so you have to sip the hot dragged through the cold cream when you're making the drink if the cream completely sinks at the bottom well there's always next time assuming you don't live in a Dairy thought the float will work best a day or two after you buy the cream from the store and you might want to throw it in the freezer for 10 minutes or so before whipping it up not enough to freeze it but just enough to get it nice and cold this classic recipe of Irish coffee originated from the Shannon Airport in Ireland in the 1940s which was a major hub for connecting North America to Europe 10 years later in the book diamonds are forever bond had an Irish coffee in the same Airport Fleming musta had one there because the drink certainly left an impression like the americano and from a view to a kill the pink gym in the man with the Golden Gun and of course the vest burn Casino Royale the ingredients are explicitly laid out for this change in the book after its taking champagne dinner bond thoroughly enjoyed the marriage of his two favorite things whiskey and coffee we're going to build this one of the glass or in this case the mug and we'll start by warming up the mug at hot water and set it aside nexel brew some coffee if you're using a French press add your grounds porn your hot water and let it steep then dump the hot water from your mug and drop in a sugar cube when your coffee is done pour in about four ounces of coffee we're just going to highball this one give it a quick stir to break down your trigger queue this will happen very quickly next we're going to measure two ounces of Irish whiskey for it in your love and give it another quick stir what's up your cream with a whisk and slowly pour it over the back of your bar spoon to preserve the layers if you're poor is like this one and not quite perfect don't worry it'll equalize on a second or two and that's all there is to it Irish coffee just the way bond likes it Slainte click here for more videos be sure to subscribe and check us out on facebook twitter and instagram

content: hello my name is Doug Miller and today I'm going to show you how to make an Irish coffee I've already started off my Irish coffee by putting little hot water into my mug to heat it up so I'm going to simply dump out that water and then from there I'm going to add some brown sugar you can use white sugar if you want you can use any type of sweetener but brown sugar just gives a little bit depth and flavor you can also add as much or as little sugar as you prefer from there I'm going to add my list you use your favorite Irish whiskey of any type to make this drink I prefer Irish whiskey / bourbon or Scotch because those will be a little bit stronger but if you don't have anything else please feel free to use any type of alcohol I want to take my spoon and just get a little stir so the drink was created in Ireland where as chef creating it for passengers on a cold flight he added some coffee some sugar some cream presented it a guest said does this Brazilian coffee said no Irish coffee and from there the drink was born it arrived to the United States in San Francisco and became a quite popular drink so now i am adding a little bit of coffee you can use decaf coffee can use regular coffee use any type of coffee that you prefer to finish off the drink I want to add a little bit of cream it should be soft cream not heavy whipped cream because when you drink it you want to title: Make Irish Coffee
content: Johnson Kenan Kenan Irish whiskey i'm here with larry sulma general manager at the historic corner vista cafe here in san francisco we're here with my irish whiskey that i did is a tribute to my great-grandfather ours is a little unique we've been in the wine industry for 130 years call it the cannon effect shift some of our use petite sirah wine barrels over there so a small portion of the whiskey after being aged 44 years is put into these wine barrels to make what we feel is a great whiskey that can be used for Irish coffee give you a little history on the Irish coffee it started in the early 40s in Ireland introduced it here in America and 1952 it's become one of the most popular drinks here making a nice profit that's a pretty easy anybody can do it starts with the proper vessels got to be a 6-ounce class it's got to be preheated to sugar cubes a couple ounces of fresh coffee you stir that until the sugar dissolves and then a very generous shot of Irish whiskey and you top it off with some lightly blended heavy cream Laurie want to thank you very much for having me out here at suena gusta café for example sister you're very welcome cheers
